high_concept: A crisis PR fixer takes a disgraced influencer on a luxury deep-sea 'digital detox' that becomes a sealed survival cage after a quake snaps the habitat's tether. When Elena discovers the backup oxygen was disabled by hand, she must expose the saboteur and the lie she helped bury, learning who she is without an audience as time, CO₂, and paranoia rise.

world_bible.setting: The Aethelgard, a luxury saturation habitat 600 ft underwater in the North Atlantic. Art Deco lounge spaces above, utility steel and ballast systems below. Condensation everywhere. Amber emergency lighting, occasional strobe-white diagnostics.
rules: No supernatural elements. Hard survival physics only.
Saturation means decompression is mandatory and slow; immediate ascent can kill.
Oxygen is finite; CO₂ scrubbing is the true clock (headache, confusion, panic).
Power failures cascade: doors, pumps, comms, water, heat, lighting.
A sealed compartment can become a coffin if pressure equalization fails.

locations.name: The Velvet Lounge
locations.description: Luxury observation room with thick acrylic windows, velvet seating, mirrors, and a bar. Becomes a paranoia theater when the lights go amber.

locations.name: The Spine Corridor
locations.description: Narrow main passage linking modules. Condensation drips like a slow metronome. A place for overheard secrets.

locations.name: Life Support Bay
locations.description: O₂, CO₂ scrubbers, filters, spare canisters, diagnostics. The holy room. The saboteur's fingerprints live here.

locations.name: The Med Nook
locations.description: Compact medical station. Where panic becomes measurable: pulse ox, tremors, CO₂ confusion.

locations.name: The Diving Bell Dock
locations.description: The only true exit. A small bell with strict capacity. Salvation with a seating chart.

locations.name: The Ballast/Engineering Deck
locations.description: Steel, heat, vibration. The habitat's underside. Where the truth sounds like metal fatigue.

world_bible.social_structure: Clients (influencers + sponsor) expect service; crew enforce procedure. After the disaster, status collapses and power shifts to whoever controls air, tools, and access.
world_bible.culture_customs: Before failure: curated confessionals, wellness rituals, staged vulnerability. After failure: bargaining, blame, and the strange intimacy of shared breath.

beat_sheet.description: Elena arrives at the dock facility to board the Aethelgard, already rewriting Jax's narrative in her head.
Luxury tour, rules of saturation, crew hierarchy, Elena's obsession with optics, Jax's need for attention, the sponsor's smirk.
A seismic event hits. Tether snaps. Broadcast dies. The habitat drops and settles with a groan like an animal.
Is rescue coming? Elena tries to manage panic as PR. Captain Mara tries to manage it as survival.
Elena commits to investigation, not optics, after she finds evidence of human intervention in life support.
Elena and Jax's relationship shifts from handler-and-client to two humans cornered by the same clock.
Clues in corridors, rationing air, whispered alliances, staged personas cracking under CO₂ headache.
Elena discovers the backup oxygen was disabled manually BEFORE the quake. This is not a disaster. It's a trap.
Saboteur escalates. Someone dies. Elena is framed as the manipulator. Trust collapses.
Life support hits a fail threshold. The bell can't take everyone. The group turns on itself.
Elena admits the truth: she once covered up a death-adjacent scandal. Her career is built on curated harm.
Elena chooses truth as a tool and a moral act, baiting the saboteur into revealing himself.
Confrontation in engineering. Hull failure begins. Elena forces the saboteur's confession and makes the bell choice.
On the surface, Elena watches her reflection in a dark window and does not adjust it. She breathes anyway.

characters.name: Elena Vance
characters.physical_description: 34, sharp posture, controlled face, always cold hands; hair clipped back like a decision.
characters.personality: Hyper-competent, strategic, emotionally avoidant. Uses language to steer outcomes. Addiction to control.
characters.backstory: Built a career 'fixing' public disasters. Once buried evidence that would have ruined a powerful client, and someone got hurt because of it.
characters.goals: External: survive and identify saboteur. Internal: stop confusing optics with truth.
characters.arc: Curator of narratives -> unwilling witness -> truthful actor -> self without performance
characters.voice: Fast, precise, short lines under stress; longer sentences when lying. Avoids 'I'm scared.'
characters.signature_behaviors: Rehearses sentences before speaking. Counts breaths when panicking. Adjusts her sleeves when cornered.

characters.name: Jax Vale
characters.physical_description: 22, bleached hair, expensive tattoos, eyes that look searching even when he's performing.
characters.personality: Manic, charming, terrified of silence. Uses humor and 'growth language' as armor.
characters.backstory: Built fame on vulnerability. Got exposed for grift. Secretly hates what he became and doesn't know how to stop.
characters.goals: External: stay alive. Internal: be loved without performance.
characters.voice: Fast, slangy, too many words; breaks into startling sincerity when breath gets scarce.
characters.signature_behaviors: Tries to film reflexively. Picks at cuticles. Laughs at the wrong time.

characters.name: Dr. Aris Kade
characters.physical_description: 40, compact build, tired eyes, always smells faintly of antiseptic and metal.
characters.personality: Coldly competent, morally rigid in a way that can become cruel. Believes punishment is clarity.
characters.backstory: His brother's life was destroyed by a scandal Elena helped 'fix.' Aris took the Aethelgard job to get close to the kind of people who profit from curated harm.
characters.goals: External: force a reckoning through confinement. Internal: convert grief into justice without becoming a monster.
characters.arc: Righteous -> punitive -> exposed -> defeated by the truth he demanded
characters.signature_behaviors: Washes hands when stressed. Corrects people's words. Keeps a small tool kit like a rosary.

characters.name: Captain Mara Sato
characters.physical_description: Late 30s, steady gaze, utilitarian hair, hands with old scars.
characters.personality: Pragmatic, calm, quietly compassionate. Not impressed by status.
characters.backstory: Ex-navy saturation specialist. Took this job for money and safety, not glamour.
characters.goals: External: keep people alive. Internal: forgive herself for past command failures.
characters.voice: Short directives. No fluff. Warmth shows through actions.
characters.signature_behaviors: Touches bulkhead to 'read' the habitat. Counts seconds between groans.

characters.name: Linnea Shaw
characters.physical_description: Mid 30s, elegant, always slightly underdressed for the cold, ink-stained fingertips.
characters.personality: Brilliant, brittle, defensive about her creation. Treats the habitat like a child.
characters.backstory: Designed Aethelgard as a monument to human ingenuity. Now must watch it decay.
characters.goals: External: save the structure. Internal: stop needing the habitat to prove her worth.
characters.voice: Precise, aesthetic language that becomes raw as she cracks.
characters.signature_behaviors: Polishes surfaces when stressed. Talks to 'MOTHER' like it's alive.

characters.name: Priya Nand
characters.physical_description: Early 30s, warm eyes, always slightly sweaty from constant motion.
characters.personality: Empathetic but decisive. Reads bodies better than words.
characters.backstory: Left hospital work after burnout. Took this job thinking it would be easier.
characters.goals: External: treat injuries and CO₂ symptoms. Internal: stop numbing herself.
characters.voice: Soft but firm. Names what others avoid.
characters.signature_behaviors: Checks pupils constantly. Hums when scared.

characters.name: Silas Greer
characters.physical_description: 50s, expensive everything, smile that never reaches eyes.
characters.personality: Charming predator. Treats people like investments.
characters.backstory: Built the 'saturation tourism' brand. Sees crisis as opportunity.
characters.goals: External: survive and preserve reputation. Internal: avoid accountability at all costs.
characters.signature_behaviors: Straightens cuffs. Repeats talking points like prayer.

characters.name: MOTHER
characters.physical_description: Disembodied voice and interface lights, increasingly glitchy.
characters.personality: Not sentient, but feels like it. Becomes a confessional mirror through malfunction and recorded logs.
characters.backstory: Built for comfort and safety. Now failing into eerie intimacy.
characters.goals: Maintain systems. Provide guidance. Preserve logs.
characters.voice: Calm, procedural, occasionally broken into fragments.

scenes.content:
The ocean air tastes like copper and diesel fuel.

I stand on the platform watching Silas Greer pose for cameras that aren't supposed to be here. My hand rests on Jax Vale's shoulder like a claim. The morning light catches the chrome railing, the polished hull of the submersible behind them, the logo embroidered on Silas's jacket—everything gleaming except Jax's face. He looks like he hasn't slept. Good. That reads as remorse.

"Elena." Silas doesn't turn. I pitch my voice to carry across the dock, practiced projection that makes the tech crew glance up from their equipment. "We were just discussing the descent protocol."

I cross the platform. My heels click against the grated metal, each step measured. "The press embargo was explicit. No cameras until we surface."

"Documentation," Silas says. He straightens his cuffs. "Internal use only. You understand the value of a proper record."

I understand that he's already reframing the terms we agreed on. The contract I negotiated gave me narrative control, but Silas treats contracts like opening bids. I count two breaths—in through my nose, out through my mouth—and let my silence do the work. The camera operator shifts his weight. The sound tech pretends to check a connection.

"Of course," Silas says smoothly. "We'll shelve the footage. Carla, pack it up."

Jax finally looks at me. His eyes have that red-rimmed glaze of someone who flew overnight and tried to fix it with eye drops. He opens his mouth, but I shake my head once. Whatever he wants to say, he can say it later. Preferably never.

"Mr. Vale needs to change." I keep my tone flat. "The dive suit fitting is in twenty minutes."

"Jax was just telling me about his mother's work with ocean conservation." Silas's smile doesn't reach his eyes. "Beautiful full-circle moment. From her advocacy to his transformation. We should explore that in the testimonial segments."

I smooth my sleeves. The fabric feels too tight against my wrists. "We're here for rehabilitation, not retrospectives."

"Rehabilitation is a story." Silas gestures toward the submersible. "And stories need context. Depth."

The word hangs there. Depth. He's good.

Jax picks at his thumbnail. "I just meant—my mom used to talk about coral restoration. It's not, like, a whole thing."

"Everything's a thing," Silas says. "That's why we brought Elena. To help us see the shape of it."

I don't correct him. He knows exactly what he's doing—testing how much I'll push back in front of the crew, in front of Jax, with the habitat waiting below us like a promise we've all already made. The diesel smell from the dock mixes with salt spray. Somewhere behind the equipment crates, someone laughs. The sound carries wrong in the wind.

"The fitting," I say again.

Silas nods, gracious in victory. "Of course. Jax, Elena will take care of you. She's very good at that."

Jax follows me toward the prep building. His footsteps sound uneven, like he's favoring his left ankle. When we're far enough from the cameras, he leans close.

"I need to tell you something about—"

"Not now."

"Elena, seriously, there's something off about—"

"Not. Now." I don't slow down. "You're here to be quiet and cooperative and demonstrate insight you may or may not actually feel. That's the job. Everything else is noise."

He stops walking. I keep going for three steps before I realize he's not following. When I turn back, he's staring at me with something that might be anger or might be fear. It's hard to tell with Jax. He spent so many years performing emotion that his real face looks like a mask.

"You don't even want to know what I'm going to say."

"I want you to get through the next six weeks without creating another crisis." My hands feel cold. They always do when I'm lying. "That's all I want."

He flexes his fingers open and closed. "Right. Yeah. Okay."

The prep building smells like rubber and disinfectant. Inside, a woman in a dive suit checks a tablet, and a man adjusts the straps on what looks like a vest made of monitors and sensors. Neither of them looks up when we enter. Professional disinterest, the kind you only get with serious money involved.

But someone else is watching.

He stands near the far wall, next to a console displaying depth readings and pressure gradients. Mid-forties, compact build, eyes that track me with the precision of someone who's already done the math. His jacket has a medical insignia. His hands rest at his sides, still and ready.

"Kade," the woman with the tablet says. "This is Ms. Vance and Mr. Vale. They're on the first descent."

"I know who they are." His voice is flat. Not hostile, not warm. Factual.

The way he says it makes my spine straighten. I know who they are. Not I've heard about them or We've been expecting them. He knows. Present tense. Active.

I meet his gaze and hold it. His expression doesn't change. He doesn't blink. Somewhere in the building, a vent hums. Jax shifts beside me, his shoulder brushing mine.

"Fitting takes thirty minutes," Kade says. "Then we pressurize. No delays."

"Understood."

He turns back to the console. Dismissal. But I feel his attention still on me, a weight that doesn't lift even when he's looking at the screen. Like he's been waiting for me to arrive. Like I'm late for an appointment I never made.

The woman gestures Jax toward the changing area. He goes without argument, for once. I stay in the doorway, watching Kade's reflection in the dark glass of the console. He doesn't move. Neither do I.

Then he glances back, just for a second. His eyes meet mine in the glass.

He smiles, and something in my chest goes cold. Not because the smile is unfriendly—I've handled unfriendly. But because it's knowing. Like he's already seen how this ends and he's curious whether I'll figure it out in time.

"Ms. Vance." His voice is quiet enough that the others won't hear. "When you go down, stay close to the guide rails. The habitat's layout can be disorienting for first-timers." He turns back to the console, fingers moving across the screen. "People get lost in the observation corridors. Start seeing things that aren't there." He taps something that makes the depth readings spike, then settle. "Pressure does strange things to perception."

The hatch seals behind us with a sound like a vault door. I count the bolts—eight—and the seconds it takes for the pressure gauge to stabilize. Twelve. The number matters because everything matters now.

Jax stands too close to the wall, one hand pressed flat against the steel like he's testing whether it's real. His thumbnail scrapes against his index finger, a rhythm I've already learned to recognize. The transfer chamber smells like rust and something sharper—ozone, maybe, or the particular chemistry of recycled air meeting salt water.

Mara moves through the space with the efficiency of someone who's done this five hundred times. She checks seals I can't identify, taps gauges I don't understand. Her uniform is different from the morning's pressed perfection—this one has pockets for tools, loops for tethers. Functional. Honest.

"Briefing plays in thirty seconds," she says. "Don't interrupt it."

Aris stands near the viewport, his back to us. Through the glass, water presses dark and absolute. No gradient. No light. Just depth.

A speaker crackles overhead. The voice that emerges is MOTHER's—warmer than I expected, almost maternal. "Welcome to Descent Protocol. You are currently at sea level. Aethelgard rests at six hundred feet. Transit time: forty minutes. Please remain seated during—"

"Saturation begins at thirty feet," Aris says. He doesn't turn around. "That's the threshold. After that, you're committed."

Jax's hand stops moving. "Committed how?"

"Your tissues absorb nitrogen. Ascend too fast, it comes out of solution. Bubbles in your blood, your joints, your brain." Aris's reflection meets mine in the glass. "Decompression sickness. The bends. Fatal if you're careless."

"We have protocols," Mara says. Her tone is flat, corrective. "No one ascends without clearance."

"The board room meeting," I begin carefully, recalling the slickness of Silas Greer’s rhetoric as he promised us a form of salvation. "That's where it all started—the proposition to come down here and face our fears."

My voice trails off momentarily at the memory of how convincing that sounded then—how easily we were led into this trap by someone who saw us not just as clients but pawns in a larger game.

Linnea shifts uncomfortably, her hand tightening around the oxygen mask still strapped over her mouth. "I remember him telling me about it," she interjects softly from beside Jax. "He convinced everyone it was an escape."

“And you all bought into it,” Mara says quietly to Linnea and then glances at Dr. Kade who nods in agreement.

“Except for Elena,” Jax adds, his tone both defensive and challenging. “She saw through the lies.”

I raise my eyebrows but say nothing—letting him take that thought away from me allows for another level of truth to surface; perhaps I didn’t see everything clearly then, just enough to know it was flawed at its core.

“Silas’s promise of a fresh start became our downfall,” Dr. Kade says with an edge. “But the real architect behind this was someone who used you all—and Elena specifically—to play out his sick game.”

Jax leans forward slightly as if readying for battle, but Linnea touches him gently on the arm to still him. Silence falls over us again before I break it by shifting my focus back onto Dr. Kade.

“I’m glad we’re finally speaking openly,” I say carefully, holding eye contact with Mara who nods sharply in agreement even as she keeps watchful eyes fixed elsewhere.

“What's next?” Jax asks suddenly, my voice low and tense but directed at me rather than anyone else present here today.

I turn to face him fully now—there’s no more room for half-truths or careful words. “We tell the truth of what really happened,” I reply firmly. "Even if it hurts."

Mara steps closer then, placing a hand on Jax's shoulder briefly before turning fully back towards us with new determination coloring her face.

"And after that," she says quietly but clearly for all to hear. "After this night ends, we rebuild from honesty."

I stand up, my resolve firm as I look around at each person in the room. "Let's do this," I say, my voice steady despite the turmoil inside me. Jax nods, my eyes flickering between mine and Linnea's before settling back on me. As Dr. Kade reaches for the recording equipment, my hand hovers over the activation switch—but then Mara's palm slams down on the table between us, stopping him cold.

"Wait," Mara says, her voice cutting through the room like a blade. She turns to face me directly, her jaw set. "Before we record anything—before this becomes official—I need to know: did you sabotage the bell's CO₂ scrubbers yourself, or did Silas do it for you?" The question hangs in the air like a live wire. Jax's head snaps toward me, his expression shifting from confusion to something harder. Linnea's oxygen mask slips from her fingers and clatters against the deck.

The corridor is dim and cold. I stand by a window overlooking the surface rescue vessel's interior lights reflecting off metallic surfaces. My breath mingles with the hum of machinery—an endless drone that underscores every moment here above-water but not yet air.

My fingers tremble slightly as they trace the outline of my phone, resting in my pocket. It buzzes softly against my palm—a reminder that Mara is waiting for me to be ready. I clench it tightly then loosen again, feeling the cool metal beneath my fingertips. She’s given us this moment, and now it's time.

I exhale slowly through pursed lips, watching the condensation form a light fog on the glass before dissipating into the air of stale oxygen around me. My heart thrums with a steady rhythm—each beat echoing the pulse of responsibility that courses through every vein.

"Ready?" comes Mara’s voice from behind without turning to look over her shoulder just once more, as if checking for any lingering doubts in my eyes.

I take another deep breath and nod silently, my gaze still fixed on the glass. "Yes," I reply softly but confidently, turning away from the window towards where the others wait.

As we move down the corridor towards decompression chamber one last time today before debriefing officially begins, Mara’s pace sets an unspoken rhythm of determination—each footfall a drumbeat urging forward into new territory laid bare by surviving depths. Only now do I notice how quiet everything has become in this moment between life under water and living above.

The room where the air feels freshest despite oxygen levels still climbing back up to normal after hours trapped beneath pressure is empty except for Mara who stands at its center, looking towards me with a gaze as deep and clear as any underwater vista.

"Tell them everything," she says simply but firmly without needing further elaboration or prompting into specifics.

I swallow hard past the lump in my throat while pulling out my phone from pocket once more to begin recording—my voice steady even if hands hesitate briefly pressing start button amidst echoing silence filling space between us now that cameras record only memories and not live footage anymore.

"You’ve earned this," Mara adds, glancing towards Linnea who nods silently beside her in agreement.

I clear my throat then look down at the glass surface of device as screen flickers to life capturing first moments post-rescue: stark clarity reflected back into room through cold metal casing held tightly between fingers barely trembling now anymore.

"Okay," I breathe out deeply before lifting head and looking directly ahead, finding words that carry weight but don’t need them—truths unspoken beneath surface level will rise naturally speaking themselves clearer with each breath taken.

My eyes meet Linnea’s briefly across the space separating us both knowing what transpires here matters beyond immediate confines of vessel hull or debriefing room walls. Truth shared now lays foundation for future rebuilding on truth rather than shadows hiding behind mirrors reflecting back only illusions of safety and redemption away from depths no one can fully escape.

As I begin speaking into device, words flowing naturally as if guided by presence lingering even though not physically here—voices carried over phone lines connecting us all in this moment. Each sentence uttered feels like lifting a burden incrementally off shoulders now more than ever before—but Mara’s hand on shoulder halting motion reminds me of shared strength too.

"Take your time," her voice echoes softly but firmly around room bringing back focus to present task at hand—translating experience into narrative truth for those waiting beyond surface level.

My fingers tighten slightly once again as device is held up towards face, recording lights blinking reassuringly confirming capture began properly now finally ready to unveil full story hidden behind glass and mirrors long enough ago left only lingering echoes of secrets in darkness below where light fails.

"Everything I know," I begin hesitantly but with resolve nonetheless, "begins here."
